title: Islamic State Releases Purported Audio Message From Leader Baghdadi
text:
BEIRUT—Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi ordered his followers to redouble their efforts to further the extremist group’s cause, in an audio message apparently aimed at raising morale after it lost control over its self-proclaimed caliphate in parts of Syria and Iraq earlier this year.

The purported Baghdadi message follows Islamic State’s April release of what was the first known video footage of him in nearly five years. Severely weakened by the five-year military campaign that forced it underground in March, the extremist group remains a potent threat after reverting to insurgency while seeking to inspire attacks globally.

“O soldiers of Allah everywhere, know that what is coming is good…so the efforts must be redoubled and one’s best must be given in all aspects, whether in preaching or media or military or security,” Baghdadi said in a 30-minute recording, according to monitoring group SITE Intelligence.

It wasn’t clear when exactly the audio was produced, but Baghdadi referred to an Islamic State campaign in August, according to SITE. The Wall Street Journal couldn’t independently confirm if the voice in the recording was that of Baghdadi.

The 48-year-old Islamic State leader has evaded capture despite the efforts of the world’s intelligence agencies and a $25 million bounty. Iraqi intelligence believes Baghdadi is hunkered down in the vast desert spanning the border between Iraq with Syria.

The audio recording’s release comes amid rising fears of a broader conflict breaking out in the region after the U.S. blamed Iran for attacks on Saudi oil infrastructure over the weekend. Tehran has denied involvement.

Western and regional military commanders have warned that tensions between Iran and the U.S. are detracting from efforts to prevent Islamic State rebuilding.

Islamic State supporters took to social media after the speech was released, posting photographs of handwritten notes hailing Baghdadi that purportedly came from Turkey, Gaza, Egypt and Sudan.

Baghdadi said the U.S. was “drowning in a quagmire” and “being bled along with its proxies” on battlefields stretching from Afghanistan and Pakistan to Iraq, Syria, Yemen, Somalia, West and Central Africa, East Asia and North Africa.

Hassan Hassan, director of the Nonstate Actors Program at the Center for Global Policy and co-author of a book about Islamic State, said the speech was more focused on the region than any other since the group proclaimed its caliphate in 2014, noting Baghdadi had hardly mentioned the West.

“This suggests that ISIS, like al Qaeda and its offshoots since 2011, will increasingly focus on countries in the Middle East and the wider region, rather than on conducting attacks on the West,” he said, using ISIS as an abbreviation for Islamic State.

A report to Congress by the Pentagon’s Office of Inspector General in August assessed that Islamic State militants were strengthening their capability to carry out attacks in Iraq and Syria.

The report said the group’s determination to make a comeback—and the difficulties encountered by U.S.- backed forces in Iraq and Syria in holding ground in remote areas—had provided a fresh opening for the militants.

The inspector general’s report linked Islamic State’s resurgence to Trump administration decisions to reduce U.S. forces in Syria, shrink the American diplomatic presence in Iraq and diverting reconnaissance systems to efforts to monitor Iranian activity in the region.

It estimated the number of Islamic State members at between 14,000 and 18,000 in Iraq and Syria, including up to 3,000 foreigners, though government estimates vary.

—Nazih Osseiran in Beirut and Ghassan Adnan in Baghdad contributed to this article.

Write to Isabel Coles at isabel.coles@wsj.com
